posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked:
Maybe we’re just being stubborn, but my team still wants to use a different origin system depending on if Red or Blue.  There are some things about doing it that way that make it easier to teach the newer kids about the standard “right hand rule” in robotics, and of course when positive X is always away from driver station it just helps keep things nice and clear for everyone.  Also, for a team that doesn’t have anything close to a full field to practice on, we feel that we’re able to get more efficient practice as either Red or Blue by swapping things around and being able to measure off our “right corner 0,0” to verify whatever it is we’re trying to do or set up.  (I know its just a little math, but still, using 0,0 is just nice and straightforward)

We know PathPlanner goes with Blue origin only, with automatic flipping.  We get that.  But besides for “playing nicely” with PathPlanner, are there other reasons to use Blue side coords only?  What are we missing?  Thanks!

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
When you use your own alliance wall as the origin, in the last two years it’s been less helpful because the field is not rotationally symmetric, so your own alliance points of interest are not in the same coordinates on each alliance anyway. Additionally with the way vision-based pose estimators work, you would have to handle the case when you switch alliance without any tags in sight, because as soon as the robot does see a tag, it will teleport across the field with potentially unexpected consequences.

When measuring a very partial field based on the alliance-specific origin, you would still need an entire field width to be able to access the origin when it is opposite from the field element. I usually recommend just measuring relative to the most critical field element.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
Coordinate systems are used in FRC programming in several places. A few of the common places are: robot movement, joystick input, pose estimation, AprilTags, and path planning. It is important to u...

This section outlines some advantages to the blue alliance origin approach as well.

link_counts.title: Coordinate System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: The big thing that killed a “Red coordinate system” for me was the Apriltags. The field may be mirror symmetric (at least in the last couple of years) but the Tags are not. So if you want to flip the coordinates when on Red, you will have to load a custom Tag layout as well. If you are using PhotonVision, that would be in the coprocessor, making it even harder.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Yup that’s what we did last year.  Custom april tag map for red pose estimation.  Red pathplanner paths did not visually make sense on the GUI, but we got past that and just focused on the coords and not the animation.  So we put extra work into the tag maps and pathplanner stuff in order to keep some other stuff easier (at least in our own minds).  We may have chose the wrong path there, but we had a pretty successful season so it’s tempting to stay course.  Will likely make the push to use blue only this year.  Thanks all for feedback.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Much like how a number plane (x/y) measures positive angles in a counter-clockwise rotation, while an actual compass measuress them postive in the clockwise rotation, it’s a matter of convention.  It’s what the community has converged on.

I had a tough time making the transition too - our autos of a couple years ago were all dead reckoning from the start point, so ‘positive’ was always away from where-ever our driver station was.

In the end though, working the absolutely amazing tools like path planner and april tags forced us to make the change as well.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: One thing to keep in mind, when the field is built by volunteers, it’s built around red, and blue is made to be the last wall up. So it’s important to remember blue is the more likely side to get knocked out of whack or have a bit less tolerance.

posts.name: alst
posts.cooked: This might be region-dependent. I don’t think I’ve ever seen someone conciously pick one field end over the other to set up first.

posts.name: Doug Frisk
posts.cooked:
From the score table, red is always on the right-hand side. If you think of the field as a piece of graph paper, 0,0 would be on the bottom left, or near side blue from the scoring table perspective. That’s almost certainly why the field is measured that way.

There’s no reason you couldn’t write your code around a different coordinate system, but why? If you use the FIRST origin, then if you are talking to others about your code, it will make sense to them. If you use another, then you have to explain your coordinate system before getting help from a CSA or another team.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC

posts.custom_user_title: The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC

posts.name: Bryan Herbst
posts.cooked:
alst:

This might be region-dependent. I don’t think I’ve ever seen someone conciously pick one field end over the other to set up first.

The field manual does instruct FTAs & Field Supervisors to mark chalk lines and assemble the side walls & red alliance end first, then chalk and assemble the blue alliance end.

In practice, there certainly can be variation and you should end up with a similar result either way.

That also does not have any bearing on the placement of a number of field elements (e.g. the STAGE in 2024), and most crucial elements are placed either by: A) measuring the distance between the two ends to find the “true” center and measuring from that. or B) placing each element the same distance from the nearest end wall

The goal is that each element is the same place from the robot’s perspective.

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked: It’s in the field build instructions to do red first. (Too slow, but I was cooking dinner)

posts.name: alst
posts.cooked:
Bryan_Herbst:

The field manual does instruct FTAs & Field Supervisors to mark chalk lines and assemble the side walls & red alliance end first, then chalk and assemble the blue alliance end.

Oh, maybe you’re referring to the “suggestions for snapping chalk lines” section? I was looking at the following section dealing with physical wall assembly.

Mainly, my point is that teams shouldn’t be counting on one wall to have been assembled before the other, although I’m not sure what competitive advantage that would really give, since human factors and minor differences between the field elements can lead to slight variations regardless of which side is set up first.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
alst:

human factors and minor differences between the field elements can lead to slight variations regardless of which side is set up first.

And if gameplay continues to be what it was last year… the walls will definitely move over the course of a competition with much greater variation than that.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
aveeser:

ustom april tag map for red pose estimation. Red pathplanner paths did not visually make sense on the GUI, but we got past that and just focused on the coords and not the animation. So we put extra work into the tag maps and pathplanner stuff in order to keep some other stuff easier

This sounds awful. Glad to hear you’re gonna try for blue-origin this year

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Haha it really wasn’t all that bad.  But yeah, we’ll plan to conform this year and hopefully in a few months we’ll be able to say “Wow, what were we thinking last year?!”.  Time will tell.  Thanks!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
So to OP’s initial comment, while we didn’t do things with two coordinate systems, the pedgagoy of how to teach students to think about the problem was important.

We solved it by saying “Assume you’re always on Blue”.

We then wrote logic to transform something on the Blue alliance side to it’s corresponding point on the red side: RobotCasserole2024/utils/allianceTransformUtils.py at main · RobotCasserole1736/RobotCasserole2024 · GitHub

Students just had to remember to design for blue, but wrap any constant value related to field position with that transform() function.

More than one bug came about from forgetting to do this, and the robot zooming to the wrong spot. Testing and code review are important.

In this way, we were able to use a single coordinate system, not have to worry about changing the Apriltag maps, but also not have to think about red vs. blue goals or coordinates or paths or anything like that.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

but wrap any constant value related to field position with that transform() function

AND since the alliance isn’t guaranteed to be known until the robot is enabled, you have to treat these “constants” as non-constants, ie functions that return the properly transformed pose as of when they’re called.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Amicus1:

AND since the alliance isn’t guaranteed to be known until the robot is enabled

That is one way of guaranteeing it, but more broadly, as long as the DS is connected to FMS , ( DriverStation.isFMSAttached() returns true) the alliance is guaranteed to be correct.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Ah true, I think I got confused previously when someone brought up robots that reboot mid-match and are enabled on their first loop post-boot.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Yup, point taken - don’t cache the value.

But ya know, being a python team, we don’t think about such silly concepts as “constant” any more
